723163f-b.title: Manhattan: St. Nicholas Avenue - Fort George Avenue
723163f-b.text:
St. Nicholas Place, east side, north across W. 150th
Street. At the right is the 6-story Audubon Court Apartments.
Adjoining same are the several buildings that house the dom-
munity Hospital in Wew York City. These are at the S. E.
corner of 150th Street. Across the street at the N. E. corner
is the reputed Ringling mansion. One, J. A. Bailey owned sase
in 1904. This individual may have been one of the famous cir-
cus owners, Barnum and Bailey, the predecessors to the present
Ringling Brothers.
H. Acker is the owner in 1910, Louis Schaefer in 1918 and
a Bertha Koemple in 1959. Adjoining this is the minaretted
A. Alexander home.
View 2 shows only the structures at the N. E. corner.
The triangular park that separates St. Nicholas Place from the
Avenue of the same name, is Donnelson Square.
Mey 19, 1940
April 19, 1940
P. L. Snerr
NO REPRODUCTIONS
No. 3
The Coamunity Howpital and it's adjoining buildings
as photographed aoross the aforementioned Donnelson Square.
June 5, 1940
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS

723163f-a.folder: St. Nicholas Avenue & Fort George Avenue, Manhattan, NY

723166f-a.title: Manhattan: St. Nicholas Avenue - Fort George Avenue
723166f-a.text:
(1)
St. Nicholas Ave., north from but not including Fort George Ave.
From this point the avenue winds down a sharp hill and reaches Nagle Ave.
at its junction with Dyckman Street and Hillside Ave. (where it terminates)
This point of vantage affords a panoramic view of the northernmost sector
of Manhattan, north from Dyckman Street, to Spuyten Duyvil. At the
right is part of Highbridge Park, and at the left is a very steep slope
reaching down to Hillside Ave.
April 24, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, from a point slightly northward. Also shown is a portion
of the Seventh Ave.-Van Cortlandt Line of the IInterborough Rapid Transit
subway, running, at this point, on an elevated structure on Nagle Ave.
April 20, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
The same, but showing a closer view of the point of confluence of
the thoroughfares mentioned in view No. 1. At the right appears Dyckman
Street as it crosses Sagle Ave. and proceeds northward. The houses seen
(left) are on the east side of Dyckman Street, north from Nagle Ave., and
(right) on the north side of the latter, east from the former street.
Also shown (extreme left) is the Dyckman Street station of the subway
line (mentioned in view 2).
April 20, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
